xxl.core.relational.cursors

Class SortBasedDivision

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<Tuple>
      • xxl.core.relational.cursors.SortBasedDivision
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator<Tuple>, Cursor<Tuple>, MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>>, MetaDataProvider<CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>>

    public class SortBasedDivision
extends AbstractCursor<Tuple>
implements MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>>
    This class provides the division operator of the relational algebra.

    Let us consider the division of R and S with R[A1,...,Ai,B1,...,Bj] and S[B1,...,Bj]. Then the result Res has schema Res[A1,...,Ai]. For every result tuple res and every tuple s from S, the tuple (res,s) is contained in R.

    In other words, the division computes all elements of R projected to the A-attributes, that are contained in R with all tuples of S.

    The division is an operation that can deliver interesting information from databases!

    This class performs a sort-merge join (R natural join S). Then, it outputs all elements projected to [A1,...,Ai] that occur exactly |S| times in the join result.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected int counter
      A counter saving the number of tuples of the second input.
      protected MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>> result

    • Constructor Detail

      • SortBasedDivision

        public SortBasedDivision(MetaDataCursor<? extends Tuple,CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>> sortedDistinctCursor1,
                         MetaDataCursor<? extends Tuple,CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>> sortedDistinctCursor2,
                         Bag<Tuple> bag,
                         Function<Object,? extends Tuple> tupleFactory)
        Constructs an instance of the sort-based division operator.
        Parameters:
        sortedDistinctCursor1 - the sorted metadata cursor (by the all attributes: order by A1, ..., Ai, B1, ..., Bj) containing elements of the first input relation (no duplicates allowed).
        sortedDistinctCursor2 - the sorted metadata cursor (by the quotient attributes) containing elements of the second input relation (no duplicates allowed).
        bag - a bag that is used for the sweep area of the internal SortMergeJoin operator.
        tupleFactory - a function that maps a list of objects (column values) to a new tuple. Classes implementing the Tuple interface should provide factory methods for this task. If null is passed, a factory method producing array-tuples is used.

      • SortBasedDivision

        public SortBasedDivision(MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>> sortedCursor1,

                         Function<Object,? extends Tuple> tupleFactory)
        Constructs an instance of the sort-based division operator. An list-bag is used for the sweep area of the internal SortMergeJoin operator.
        Parameters:
        sortedCursor1 - the sorted metadata cursor (by the all attributes: order by A1, ..., Ai, B1, ..., Bj) containing elements of the first input relation.
        sortedCursor2 - the sorted metadata cursor (by the quotient attributes) containing elements of the second input relation.
        tupleFactory - a function that maps a list of objects (column values) to a new tuple. Classes implementing the Tuple interface should provide factory methods for this task. If null is passed, a factory method producing array-tuples is used.

      • nextObject

        public Tuple nextObject()
        Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.
        Specified by:
        nextObject in class AbstractCursor<Tuple>
        Returns:
        the next element in the iteration.

      • reset

        public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
        Resets the cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new cursor (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

        Note, that this operation is optional and does not work for this cursor.

        Specified by:
        reset in interface Cursor<Tuple>
        Overrides:
        reset in class AbstractCursor<Tuple>
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the cursor.

      • supportsReset

        public boolean supportsReset()
        Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.
        Specified by:
        supportsReset in interface Cursor<Tuple>
        Overrides:
        supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<Tuple>
        Returns:
        true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close files, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

        Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

        Specified by:
        close in interface Cursor<Tuple>
        Overrides:
        close in class AbstractCursor<Tuple>
